votes.title: Item 5 - Lancashire Combined County Authority and Devolution Deal - Labour Amendment
votes.description: Labour amendment to the Lancashire Combined County Authority (LCCA) devolution proposal, seeking to give the 12 district councils full voting rights on the new combined authority and to delegate UK Shared Prosperity Fund delivery to districts. The Conservative administration's model proposed upper-tier-only voting membership.
key_facts: District councils would gain full voting rights on the LCCA under this amendment
UK Shared Prosperity Fund delivery would be delegated to districts
3 Liberal Democrat councillors abstained — signalling cross-party unease about sidelining districts
Cllr Michael Green declared a non-pecuniary interest as a South Ribble Borough Council member

votes_by_councillor.name: County Councillor Anne Cheetham OBE JP
County Councillor Munsif Dad BEM JP
County Councillor John R Singleton JP

votes.title: Item 5 - Lancashire Combined County Authority and Devolution Deal
votes.description: Formal approval to submit the Lancashire Combined County Authority proposal to the Secretary of State, creating a combined authority covering Lancashire CC, Blackpool, and Blackburn with Darwen with devolved powers over transport, housing, skills, and economic development.
key_facts: Creates the LCCA covering Lancashire's 3 upper-tier councils
Devolved powers over transport, housing, skills, economic development
Liberal Democrats joined Conservatives in voting For on the main motion
Labour and Greens voted against despite supporting the consultation phase unanimously in November 2023
District councils have no voting membership on the LCCA

votes_by_councillor.name: County Councillor Munsif Dad BEM JP
County Councillor John R Singleton JP

votes.title: Notice of Motion 4 - Water Companies
votes.description: Motion on water company accountability prompted by raw sewage discharges on the Fylde Coast during the 2023 tourist season and United Utilities' proposal to raise bills while making £426m in six-month profits. The Conservative amendment was adopted, softening the original Labour motion.
key_facts: Original Labour motion targeted corporate greed and shareholder dividends
Conservative amendment (Cllr Shaun Turner / Cllr Stephen Clarke) reframed as infrastructure challenge
Lib Dem amendment proposed a sewage tax on profits — rejected
Conservative amendment corrected location from 'Blackpool and the Fylde Coast' to 'Fleetwood' (a burst outfall pipe)
28 voted against the watered-down final motion — Labour, Green and Lib Dem opposition

votes_by_councillor.name: County Councillor Anne Cheetham OBE JP
County Councillor Munsif Dad BEM JP
County Councillor John R Singleton JP

votes.meeting: Extraordinary General Meeting, Full Council, Monday, 27th November, 2023 10.30 am
votes.title: Item 3 - Lancashire Combined County Authority and Devolution Proposal
votes.description: Unanimous approval to launch an 8-week public consultation on creating the Lancashire Combined County Authority, following the government's Autumn Budget Statement announcement. All three upper-tier councils considered the same report. A rare moment of total cross-party agreement.
key_facts: Passed unanimously 58-0-0 — every councillor present voted For
Labour procedural amendment seeking a 30% response threshold for extending consultation was defeated first
Green procedural amendment attempted to change 'agree' to 'note' — withdrawn after legal advice
The unanimous vote contrasts sharply with the 46-28 vote 4 months later on the formal submission
Cllr Azhar Ali OBE proposed the Labour amendment — later suspended by Labour before the 2024 general election

votes_by_councillor.name: County Councillor Anne Cheetham OBE JP
County Councillor John R Singleton JP

votes.title: Policy Position on the Future Provision of Halal Meat
votes.description: Policy to require that all meat (except poultry) supplied to Lancashire County Council establishments must come from animals stunned before slaughter. One of the most culturally sensitive votes in LCC's recent history, pitting animal welfare against religious freedom.
key_facts: Proposed by the Leader himself — giving it maximum political weight
27 schools across multiple districts were affected
Vote split along cultural and religious lines rather than party lines
Muslim councillors overwhelmingly voted against
Poultry exemption and commitment to consult the Lancashire Council of Mosques were compromise measures
Generated significant national media coverage and community tension in Burnley, Pendle and Blackburn

votes_by_councillor.name: County Councillor Anne Cheetham OBE JP
County Councillor Munsif Dad BEM JP

votes.title: Charter Against Modern Day Slavery
votes.description: Labour motion for LCC to sign the Co-operative Party Charter Against Modern Slavery, committing to procurement safeguards and supply chain transparency. The Conservative amendment accepted the principle but removed the formal charter signing.
key_facts: Conservative amendment (Cllr Geoff Driver / Cllr Albert Atkinson) reframed as 'we already comply'
Dropped the explicit commitment to sign a Co-operative Party (Labour-aligned) charter
New commitments: contractor whistleblowing policies, NCA referral mechanism, annual Cabinet reporting
Classic example of the ruling group co-opting an opposition motion while removing politically inconvenient elements
Some Liberal Democrats voted with Conservatives on the amendment

votes_by_councillor.name: County Councillor Anne Cheetham OBE JP

votes.title: Our Health Our Care A&E Proposals
votes.description: Labour motion opposing NHS proposals to consolidate A&E services in central Lancashire to a single site. The Conservative amendment replaced the strong opposition stance with a call for full NHS consultation, arguing it was premature to take a position.
key_facts: Chorley A&E had been downgraded to an urgent care centre in 2016
Labour motion: 'strongly opposes any proposal for a single site A&E'
Conservative amendment (Cllr Shaun Turner / Cllr Charles Edwards): called for consultation first
Intensely local issue for Chorley and South Ribble councillors
Both motion proposers (Snape, Tomlinson) were South Ribble Labour councillors with direct constituency interest
Cllr Shaun Turner was the go-to Conservative amendment mover — also moved the Water Companies amendment

votes_by_councillor.name: County Councillor Anne Cheetham OBE JP

votes.meeting: Budget Meeting, Full Council, Friday, 23rd February, 2024 10.30 am
votes.title: Budget 2024/25 - Labour Amendment
votes.description: Labour amendment to the 2024/25 budget proposing to remove parking income and young persons' travel savings, and add £35 million in capital spending for looked-after children's care, district council housing, and urgent highway repairs.
key_facts: Proposed removing parking pay-and-display income savings (GET007)
Proposed removing young persons' travel savings (GET008)
£5m capital for in-house looked-after children's care provision
£20m assisted housing fund delegated to district councils
£10m for urgent highway repairs
S151 officer warned this would create a 2025/26 deficit of £10.885m
Lost 32-42 on strict party lines

votes_by_councillor.name: County Councillor Anne Cheetham OBE JP
County Councillor Munsif Dad BEM JP
County Councillor John R Singleton JP

votes.meeting: Budget Meeting, Full Council, Friday, 23rd February, 2024 10.30 am
votes.title: Budget 2024/25 - Liberal Democrats Amendment
votes.description: Liberal Democrat amendment to the 2024/25 budget proposing 6 additional youth workers, 12 parking enforcement officers (one per district), tree planting, and halving the pothole intervention threshold from 40mm to 20mm.
key_facts: 6 additional youth workers + 1 senior (£297k revenue)
12 parking enforcement officers — one per district (£357k revenue)
Tree planting at £2,500 per division (£210k revenue)
Halving pothole intervention threshold from 40mm to 20mm (£4.5m capital, recurrent)
S151 officer warned this would create a 2025/26 deficit of £15.852m
Lost 31-41 — all opposition groups voted together for each other's amendments

votes_by_councillor.name: County Councillor Anne Cheetham OBE JP
County Councillor Munsif Dad BEM JP
County Councillor John R Singleton JP

votes.meeting: Budget Meeting, Full Council, Friday, 23rd February, 2024 10.30 am
votes.title: Budget 2024/25 - The Green Group Amendment
votes.description: Green Group amendment to the 2024/25 budget proposing a modest £40,000 for on-site renewable energy feasibility studies on council-owned land, including 23 landfill sites. The S151 officer confirmed this could be funded from the Transitional Reserve.
key_facts: Most modest of the 3 amendments — just £40k
On-site renewable energy feasibility studies on council-owned land
23 landfill sites identified as potential sites
S151 officer confirmed it could be funded from the £165m Transitional Reserve
Despite minimal fiscal risk, lost 31-40 on party lines
All opposition groups voted together — revealing the Conservative bloc vote rather than fiscal objection

votes_by_councillor.name: County Councillor Anne Cheetham OBE JP
County Councillor Munsif Dad BEM JP
County Councillor John R Singleton JP

votes.meeting: Budget Meeting, Full Council, Friday, 23rd February, 2024 10.30 am
votes.title: Budget 2024/25
votes.description: The Conservative administration's main revenue and capital budget for 2024/25, including a 4.99% council tax increase (2.99% core + 2% Adult Social Care precept), setting Band D at £1,653.29. The last full LCC budget before devolution deal progression.
votes.council_tax_change: 4.99% increase (2.99% core + 2% Adult Social Care precept). Band D set at £1,653.29
key_facts: 4.99% total council tax increase — the maximum without a referendum
2.99% core increase was the Localism Act 2011 referendum threshold
Transitional Reserve stood at £165.198m (forecast March 2024)
Collection fund deficit of £2.079m from districts (vs historic £5m surplus)
Squeezed by £7.079m swing on collection fund positions
Home to School Transport demand pressures were a major cost driver
Opposition groups voted against after all three amendments were rejected
Carried 40-29 — comfortable Conservative majority of 11
Cllr Lian Pate declared a non-pecuniary interest (partner was a council employee)

votes_by_councillor.name: County Councillor Anne Cheetham OBE JP
County Councillor Munsif Dad BEM JP
County Councillor John R Singleton JP
